thread.title: Small companies in the North East want next Government to prioritise regional growth

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Small companies in the North East want next Government to prioritise regional growth
text:
Business Small companies in the North East want next Government to prioritise regional growth Research by the Federation of Small Businesses finds that North East firms are most concerned about re-balancing the economy Share Ted Salmon, North East regional chairman of the Federation of Small Businesses (Photo: handout from FSB) Share Get business   
Small businesses in the North East are the most likely to want the next Government to re-balance the economy towards underperforming regions, new research suggests. 
The survey by the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB) found that 55% of small companies in the North want regional growth to be a priority for the new administration, much higher than any other area of the country and considerably above the UK average of 35%. 
Investment in infrastructure (40%) is another key demand from firms in the North East alongside delivery of a good Brexit deal (57%). 
The region’s small businesses are also the most likely to want the new Government to address social security and pensions inequality faced by the self-employed. More than half (52%) of firms want this to be a Government priority. 
The FSB represents hundreds of small firms in the North East and has become an increasingly powerful voice with the Government after remaining neutral during the Brexit referendum. 
But the organisation clashed with Ministers earlier this year after moves in the Budget to change tax rates for the self-employed, a move that was eventually dropped. 
Ted Salmon, FSB regional chairman in the North East, said: “We’ve heard promising noises over the last few years about the Northern Powerhouse and an ambitious Industrial Strategy. 
“The new Government must take the opportunity to fully deliver on these initiatives. Our members are at the heart of the economy, so it must think small first if it wants that delivery to be a success. Read More Virgin Money helps women back to work with scheme for career breakers 
“Brexit talks will no doubt form the backdrop of the next Parliament, but it’s vital that the Government doesn’t overlook domestic issues. 
“Firms across the North East are having to battle surging costs every day. We need to see the next Government simplify the tax system, raise the Employment Allowance and freeze fuel duty to help them combat cost pressures. 
“Then there’s the entrepreneurial army of self-employed workers, now 4.8m strong. The next Government must rule out any tax grab on these strivers and reform the social security system so they receive the fair treatment they deserve.” 
According to the FSB research, the largest concerns for small firms in the North East for the coming five years are increasing taxes, rising business costs and the regulatory burden. Read More John Lewis tops Linkedin's list of best places to work in the UK 
In its Small Business: Big Ambition manifesto, FSB is calling on the next Government to build opportunities across every region of the UK by implementing an Industrial Strategy that works for firms of all sizes, invest in road and aviation infrastructure and improve digital connectivity. 
It also wants the new administration to protect state pension and childcare reforms that have benefitted the self-employed and reform the Universal Credit system to make it more compatible with self-employment. Like us on Facebook
